title: Giorgio Chiellini on preparing for his first full MLS season and Juventu current scandal

The hunger for team success and to prove to the world that he is still an elite center back drove him to leave Italy for Los Angeles at the beginning of January, while most of his LA teammates were still on vacation. Given his experience in Europe, where the summer offseason period typically lasts around a month and a half, the extended two-month break between lifting MLS Cup and officially reporting back for preseason training meant he was champing at the bit to return.
â€œI stayed in Los Angeles throughout November for my daughterâ€™s school, but I spent December back home in Italy. I need other players around me, and for the first two weeks of January, it was difficult.â€

The period was more challenging as the rest of the world was celebrating the World Cup, a tournament he failed to reach following Italyâ€™s shocking defeat to North Macedonia in a win-or-go-home World Cup qualifier last March. For Chiellini, who led Italy to a European Championship win against England in 2021, the pain of missing what would have been his final major tournament in an Italy shirt was still too fresh.

Not only did he arrive in Los Angeles with footballing success on his mind, but for he and his family to undergo a cultural enrichment in a city that people from 140 countries, speaking 224 languages, call home. Like many Europeans, Chiellini found the initial adjustment from walkable communities to the car-centric life in Los Angeles challenging. Now Iâ€™m learning about schools, life, and football; I am starting to settle in more. In the beginning, it was not so easy. Thereâ€™s not a walkable city center; you must have a car. While Chiellini has settled into life in Los Angeles, the draw of home remains. His contract, worth $1.075 million, according to MLS Playersâ€™ Association, expires at the end of the season, and he makes no assurances on his future, with retirement on the horizon.
Back in Turin, where he earned his global reputation with Juventus, dysfunction and scandal have led to the Old Lady being docked 15 points after a case around alleged inflated transfer fees was reopened by an Italian court.
